topic.title: ZeroNet on a temporary Mesh Network used during natural disasters
topic.body:
We know that during natural disasters, phonelines, internet connections, television and cellphone connections tend to either get overwhelmed or just malfunction completely.

Imagine if people were able to share ZeroNet website-based updates on the situation via a local area Mesh Network? Rather than mere text updates, imagine if we were able to share media content and more content-rich updates to help people during an emergency? We know how critical Mesh Network-capable apps like FireChat were during protests in Egypt and Hong Kong:

http://www.networkworld.com/article/2691105/opensource-subnet/mesh-networks-and-firechat-how-hong-kong-protestors-are-keeping-communications-alive.html

Now imagine if ZeroNet was able to serve websites using this Mesh Networking capability?

I think a specially adapted version of the ZeroNet software could be developed with Mesh network capabilities like FireChat. It would be possible to integrate an Open Source Mesh Network technology like Hyperboria: http://hyperboria.net/ and combine it with ZeroNet, and the phones BlueTooth and Wifi capabilities.

topic.title: What is RetroShare?
topic.body:
Today is the first time I have heard about it but from what I read about it seem seems to tick most of the boxes:


https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RetroShare
https://github.com/RetroShare


It uses Tor and uses swarm technology to make it distributed, thereby eliminating servers and associated Metadata. 


The only thing I am unsure about is what type of encryption it uses. Would it be technically feasible to implement OMEMO encryption in this?


Many people find telegram useful because it offers a very convenient group collaboration feature. But Telegram is totally insecure. RetroShare seems like a good alternative. Especially if it offers offline delivery. It's also has a portable installation option, so there won't be registry entries all over the place which can compromise your security by revealing that you used it. You can just hide the entire installation inside a VeraCrypt Hidden Volume.


What are your thoughts? Perhaps the sourcecode of RetroShare or another secure collaboration software like Conversations.im can be integrated into ZeroNet and used as a standard private collaboration utility for ZeroNet users?


They even talk about implementing ZeroNet technology:

https://twitter.com/retroshare/status/709026477241737220

topic.title: ZeroNet site update issues on Linux Mint 17.3 64Bit: A Tip
topic.body:
Sometimes ZeroNet websites may not update on Linux. You may find a situation where you upload a site from Windows into ZeroNet and everything has uploaded fine, and you can see the updated site on your browser and on Windows-based ZeroNet proxies. But on Linux it shows the old website. In my case I had ZeroNet installed in a Linux Mint 17.3 64Bit VirtualBox Virtual machine with ZeroNet installed. But it showed the old website no matter how many times I clicked update.


The issue is that the ZeroNet data files (located in the ZeroBundle folder) for each site on Linux has been locked and doesn't have write permissions, so ZeroNet will fail to update. Therefore you have to open the folder as root and then update the website through the ZeroNet homepage. Then the update will work.


Perhaps there is an easier way? Please feel free to make suggestions.

topic.title: ZeroNet important software repository
topic.body:
I am thinking of creating a software repository for important software revolving around privacy, encryption, communication and others.

My reasoning is that in certain jurisdictions or for targetted individuals, it would be possible for law enforcement or intelligence agencies to perform a Man In The Middle attack (MITM) everytime somebody searches for security software, and redirect their browser to an identical copy of the website featuring hacked software/apps.

This technique is used by the NSA and is known as "FoxAcid":

https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20131004/10522324753/how-nsa-pulls-off-man-in-the-middle-attacks-with-help-telcos.shtml

My proposal is to create a P2P decentralised software repository hosted on ZeroNet which hosts software which has been identified as critical by the privacy community. 

ZeroNet is the perfect medium for this as ZeroNet websites cannot be hacked or have a MITM attack performed on them.

What I would like is:

1. Someone to help me
2. People in general suggesting software that should be hosted, which they feel is most important.
3. People from different locations around the world performing checksum checks on the software and giving the checksums here, so that I can compare them. We have to assume that a single person downloading this software and checking the chcksum is a single point of failure. Therefore we need multiple people from different locations around the world to independently verify the checksums and give them here, so that I can put them in a software repository.

What do you think? I am not a programmer BTW, so some help from an experienced person would be greatly appreciated.

topic.title: SafePress - a Framework to develop websites for MaidSafe. Possible for ZeroNet?
topic.body:
Do you think that this can be adapted for ZeroNet to allow us to make websites easily in a similar way to WordPress?

https://apps.safenetwork.org/safepress/
http://safepress.io/

Using just HTML, CSS and Javascript you will be able to build a dynamic website using SAFEpress without needing to learn about the SAFE Network or its programming interface (API). On SAFE Network, your application and your users will be secure, with all data protected from loss, interception or theft.

So that's our first target, to create the SAFEpress framework web developers and front-end folk will use to create websites with a simple Javascript API, defined using the dreamcode philosophy. (Dreamcode is the term for a Javascript API written exactly as a front-end developer would imagine it—hence "dream code"—with no need to be concerned with how the backend works. The SAFEpress / SAFE Network architecture is inherently a nobackend system, so it's very natural that we are adopting the dreamcode approach, and empowering front-end developers.)

SAFEpress can then enhanced to provide Content Management: interactive creation of pages, blog posts and other document types, so that will be our second target.

Finally SAFEpress can develop to provide dynamic and interactive customisation of not just the content, but the user interface, theme and design, even beyond where WordPress is at this point.

topic.title: Zero WikiNews Portal
topic.body:
Just hypothesizing. Imaging having a ZeroNet WikiNews Portal in the same manner as Yahoo News (https://www.yahoo.com/news/) or MSN news (http://www.msn.com/en-us/)? A distributed news portal with multiple editors who can edit the news using a shared private cryptographic key. The news portal can feature uncensored news or feature opinions not acceptable in the mass medias editorial modus operandi.

What type of software would be needed to host such a website on ZeroNet? Would it need to be integrated with the ZeroNet database API?

Also another thought. Imagine having a website where there are multiple editors. But in order to track which editor makes specific changes, how will ZeroNet allow that to be found out? Is Bitcoin cryptography capable of using multiple secret cryptographic signatures to sign a specific document or make changes to a website, and is this loggable?

So I imagine ZeroNet can also be used in a similar fashion to serve IPFS-hosted decentralised videos/pdfs/content while serving P2P websites via ZeroNet. Perhaps this is an area of research for ZeroNet website developers.

A question about IPFS. It may be based on my misunderstanding but here goes. IPFS is like a global decentralised P2P cloud storage, made up of nodes who host distributed content. Each file served has it's own unique hash.

Would it be possible for all nodes to come together and ban particular files hosted on the IPFS network by forbidding its hash? So wouldn't this be a type of censorship?

> [fancypants](#comment_2_15k25aCTwyHfXnqtqpRvBbkDz5ka7gFuuU): IPFS will allow blacklisting of hashes and has proposed the idea to build one to block illegal content at the gateway, this is just so they can comply with requests for content notice take downs. Its not censorship since users on the network will have to opt-in to the blacklist so they can't view possibly dangerous content.

Thanks. Where can I read up about this proposal? I haven't really followed the debates taking place within the IPFS developer community and I am not sure where I can read up about this blacklisting.

> [fancypants](#comment_4_15k25aCTwyHfXnqtqpRvBbkDz5ka7gFuuU): https://github.com/ipfs/faq/issues/9
> I'm still fairly new to it too and just have been playing around with the network for a couple weeks.

This one is interesting also. In essence, what it means is that IPFS is not uncensorable. It can be censored if all nodes within the network share blocklists of forbidden content. And IPFS developers are actively building-in capability to make this process easier: https://github.com/ipfs/faq/issues/36

There is also talk that a blocklist will be universally hard-coded into the software which can be auto-updated. This means even those people who planned to have nodes which don't subscribe to blocklists will also be forced to subscribe to blocklists. Looks like it is not uncensorable at all.

> [fancypants](#comment_6_15k25aCTwyHfXnqtqpRvBbkDz5ka7gFuuU): I believe, and hope, the devs understand how much censoring or adding the ability to easily censor will affect them and their project. Hard-coded blocklists will quickly kill support for the project and likely sprout a new project based off of IPFS to make censorship harder/impossible.
> I think opt-in blocklists are the way to go if there has to be a blocklist.  Having every node adopting an opt-in blocklist sounds nearly impossible, there will always be access to "blocked content". 
> Although, if you think about it, a blocklist seems entirely impossible. If I host a file that gets blocked, I'll just change the file ever so slightly so it gets a new hash that is unblocked. This would result in over-population of both a blocklist and IPFS's network itself. So, attempting to censor the network will simply be circumvented but at a cost to how much the network can store.

I agree that blocklists, if they are to be implemented, should only be done so they are voluntary, and that no built-in incentive scheme is implemented to make people do blocklists because it's in their interests. On the other hand, taking the project offshore may help. I suspect the US government saw the potential of uncensorable internet and had a word with Juan Bennet.

I think though with the ever-changing hashes that you propose as a workaround, it may seem like a monumental task. This is because such blocklists may be based off merkle trees in the same way that the Blockchain compresses historical information into a merkle tree. This means the blocklist can stores many decades worth of data before it becomes unweildy.

I think the technology should be forked and taken to a jurisdiction where there is no pressure to implement blocklists. or at least where blocklists are done voluntarily only.

1_1NhxEZGje74GQWUdX4frXE3TUg8evizrSS.body:
Zeronet works with the Tor Browser. So all the privacy-enhancements featured within the Tor Browser can be used in conjunction with ZeroNet. See this:

https://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/faq/#how-to-use-zeronet-in-tor-browser

How to use ZeroNet in Tor browser?

In Tor mode it's recommended to use ZeroNet in Tor Browser:

    Start the Tor Browser
    Go to address about:preferences#advanced
    Click Settings...
    Enter 127.0.0.1 to field No proxy for

Btw, I had trouble using the settings Above. I found the appropriate settings in the Tor browser by going to Preferences, choosing Advanced, Network, then Settings. Then pasting in 127.0.0.1 in the "No proxy for" box.

> [quadrangle](#comment_7_1CTut2qbaj54ZjNoYeuWSGwV75iVieKY6N): Good, I don't want child porn on my computer.

Then don't download it (im sure you don't). This idea that without censorship, you will end up with CP on your computer is just wrong. You are no more likely to get CP on your computer with ZeroNet than on the clearnet. And if you did accidentally view a CP website, just delete it from the sidebar. It gets wiped out from your computer.
Expect to see a lot more of this FUD as ZeroNet becomes more well-known and law enforcement become more concerned about ZeroNets uncensorable nature :)

It's a red herring the constantly bring up the issues of CP as if that is a guarantee that you will download it. You are just as likely to accidentally download CP on the clearnet. I think these calls to implement software-based censorship into ZeroNet go further than just the issue of accidentally being a node to CP. You know full-well that you can delete any site you find objectionable, so in that respect it is no different to the clearnet. So why these calls to bring censorship?

The first step into bringing censorship into ZeroNet is to hardcode a capability into ZeroNet to blacklist websites. Then it moves onto distributing this blacklist as part of the software. Then the choice of opting into these blacklists get removed from the user. This is exactly what we saw with IPFS.

> [paintninja](#comment_9_12EgeG4vgNHzuPJYZqVJQwy2W9vkywbQQu): Not censorship, but a warning system without any specific URLs. It's a lot less hassle for someone to see a warning and click a back button on their browser than to see potentially disturbing content, and then needing to manually find the folder to delete it before closing the tab. A warning appears when the content of the page matches certain keywords and the user could turn the warning system off entirely if they wish or skip the warning on a per-page basis.

The problem with such a filter is that it actively filters content. Perhaps it won't block it, but being able to identify it by keyword is the first stage in being able to block it, even if that is not something you have planned. It provides the technological ability to do so.

I think a better solution is to develop a separate plugin which allows this capability, but would be voluntary due to it being a plugin, rather than building it into ZeroNet itself. Having it built into ZeroNet means the technological capability exists to censor content, and all it would take is some form of political shift in the views of the developers or for the Law Enforcement to pressure them, for it to end up becoming a content blocker rather than a keyword filter/warning system.

Plus, who decides what keywords to filter? What makes your definition of unacceptable better than someone elses? Imagine if the definition of acceptable speech in the European Union is stricter than the US, and because of it, they force the developers to add keywords which are more prohibitive compared to the rest of the world? Who decides what an acceptable keyword is?

I'd also like to add that ZeroNet is nothing but a protocal, in the same way that http is a protocal. I don't think we should block content on the protocal level. if anything, we could block content on a plugin level.

Think of Firefox. It is a browser which enables you to view content. But if you want to block content, just use one of the numerous addons for Firefox. No one expects content filtering to be hard-coded into Firefox.

I don't think we ought to change the protocal itself in order to block or flag up certain types of content. We don't expect http to automatically block content or warn against it. neither should we have the same standard for ZeroNet. Although having a plugin system would be a good way to alleviate the concerns of people who are worried about seeding illegal content by accident.

> [armchairgenius](#comment_2_1DW9EhqZ7rndNKZTPbdxsttBU1jGtT2soT): Honestly, I'd much rather the devs work on improving and testing the security/encryption rather than trying to start censoring content. There are two reasons behind this, A) If the crypto and security is good enough, others won't know that you're hosting potentially illegal content in the first place and B) Sure, most people can agree that censoring CP is reasonable, but that starts a slippery slope towards more censorship. First against things which aren't actually illegal, just questionable or representing opinions that others don't like, then suppressing unwanted content.

And this is what a lot of us are worried about. Pretty much all people here hate child porn. But by building in technological filters to block "unwanted content" or even warn against it, we can't predict what this filter would be used for in the future, especially when governments start pressuring the developers in the same way that the makers of IPFS were.

I think it would be better to keep the ZeroNet protocal free from such filters, but to create a separate and voluntary plugin for those worried about child porn or other illegal content.

> meanwhile, I see no broken links in your page.https://imgur.com/a/wtnmk

Does that mean I have to disable javascript? And disable it on the browser or within HtTrack?

I have resolved the issue. The issue was that WordPress 4.4 had new support for srcset images, which creates multiple sizes of a single image. When I copied the site and images, the main image pointed towards localhost, but the remaining srcset images pointed towards the actual http clearnet website. That prevented the images appearing when I turned the XAMPP server off.

There are some workarounds:

1. Host a copy of WordPress on your XAMPP server lower than version 4.4. Any version lower than version 4.4 does not have srcset images, and you can freely copy the website using HTTrack and host it on ZeroNet.

2. Another solution is to manually removal all the srcset images in the html files via a html editor. That is long and laborious.

3. A third option is to edit the functions.php file in your WordPress XAMPP installation and remove the srcset functionality. This thread explains it:
http://wordpress.stackexchange.com/questions/211375/how-do-i-disable-responsive-images-in-wp-4-4

I chose option 1 as its the easiest. Because the site would be hosted on ZeroNet, there would be no need to upgrade to the latest version of WordPress since ZeroNet websites cannot be hacked through vulnerabilities in the software used to create them (such as WordPress) as they can only be modified by the Private Crypto Key.

So this is how you can maintain a well-designed WordPress site on Zeronet,  at least till the standard Zeronet software gets a wordpress CMS equivalent.

I think once a few Torrent site owners decide they want to stay alive by moving over to Decentralised websites, we will see a flood of developmental expertise coming into ZeroNet. I already read about some Gambling site owner who has a part time programmer working on a ZeroNet website. Once the big guys see ZeroNet's potential, we will see them sponsor a lot of talent to make professional websites and services for ZeroNet.

In the meantime I think the default ZeroNet blog could do with some type of WordPress admin interface with customisations and themes being configurable. That would do a lot to bring exciting content to ZeroNet. The blog also needs one-click media support. Right now we have to use markdown language, which is simple, but will turn off casual users.

20_1CMjV2r4EBpFt8VCcWWZKDysZXPcPExRNN.body:
> [deafboy](#comment_34_1xf9XC4Nsa7YfQWFiK6xGsNDJA3AaCTUa): As a new bitcoin user, avoid brain wallets. They may seem simple, but it's easy to make a mistake while spending from it.
> If you have a smartphone, use that as your wallet. Some good Android wallets:Bitcoin Wallet - Completely decentralized SPV wallet that communicates in the P2P network to check incoming payments and broadcast outgoing payments. I'm using it for basic daily expenses.Mycelium - Payments and balance checks are done by a central server, but you're still in complete control of your private keys. It can work with trust zone on some ARM phones and supports Trezor and Ledger hardware wallets via USB cable.Copay - Multi-signature wallet. You can share a wallet with someone, or use it as 2FA. It relays on BitPay servers, but as with Mycelium you're in control of your private keys.
> For iPhone:Breadwallet - Not an iPhone user myself, so I can't tell you much, but AFAIK it's also an SPV wallet and you're in control of the private keys.
> Most wallets will ask you to make a backup right away. Please do not ignore it and make a backup. It will save your ass when you least expect it. In case of Mycelium, it will give you a 12 word seed. Write it down on a piece of paper. Bitcoin Wallet (by Andreas Schildbach) will give you password-protected file. Use a good password and copy it to some place other than your phone. Not sure about Copay or Breadwallet but the process should be similar.
> BE CAREFULL WITH APPLE APPSTORE. THERE HAS BEEN SEVERAL CASES OF FAKE BITCOIN WALLETS REPORTED LATELY. More info on r/bitcoin

Much appreciated. Do any of them ask for ID verification or phone verification?

1_1FCqLq42pcBRtdUQXfKghRxhtsMKVfrDmW.body:
> [klauszimmermann](#comment_44_15QGRquMETTn5LnCHjTm1qa9eaXGtq7gpT): I believe that ZeroMail has largely replaced its functionality in a better way, since it's also built on top of the excellent ZeroNet network.

Does it fully replace its functionality though? Because BitMessage sends the data to all nodes and then sends it to the recipient. This ensures there is no metadata trail linking one a senders account to a recipients. Is that the case with ZeroMail? I am not quite sure how the architecture works, if someone doesn't mind explaining it.

> [nofish](#comment_737_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): ZeroMail works similar, but the main difference is it's using zeroid identities instead of PoW, so it's leaves more metadata. Because of that zeromail is not a replacement and bitmessage still more secure. (it could be possible to implement pow based files in zeronet, but i'm not big fan of pow)

Thanks for the clarification. Yes, it would be great if a system similar to BitMessage can be implemented.
